review.title: Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems and Applications: A Survey
review.abstract: The field of Multi-Agent System (MAS) is an active area of research within Artificial Intelligence, with an increasingly important impact in industrial and other real-world applications. Within a MAS, autonomous agents interact to pursue personal interests and/or to achieve common objectives. Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs) have emerged as one of the prominent agent architectures to govern the agents' autonomous behavior, where both algorithms and communication models are driven by the structure of the specific problem. During the last decade, several extensions to the DCOP model have enabled them to support MAS in complex, real-time, and uncertain environments.

metadata.title: Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems and Applications: A Survey

sections.text: In an MAS, autonomous actors interact to pursue personal interests and / or achieve common goals. Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs) have become a prominent agent model for controlling the autonomous behavior of actors, with both algorithms and communication models driven by the structure of the specific problem. In the last decade, several enhancements to the DCOP model have been proposed to support MAS in complex, real-time and uncertain environments. This survey provides an overview of the DCOP model, provides a classification of its multiple enhancements, and addresses both solution methods and applications that find a natural mapping within each class of DCOPs. The proposed classification proposes several future perspectives for DCOP enhancements and identifies challenges in designing efficient solution algorithms, possibly by adapting strategies from different areas.

sections.heading: 2. Overview of (Distributed) Constraint Satisfaction and Optimization
sections.text: In this section, we give an overview of several constraint satisfaction models that form the basis of the DCOPs. Figure 2 illustrates the relationships between these models.

sections.heading: 2.1 Constraint Satisfaction Problems
sections.text: Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs) (Golomb & Baumert, 1965; Mackworth & Freuder, 1985; Apt, 2003; Rossi et al., 2006) are decision-making problems involving the assignment of values to variables, under a number of specified constraints on how variable values should be related to each other. A number of problems can be formulated as CSPs, including resource allocation, vehicle routing, circuit diagnosis, planning, and bioinformatics. Over the years, CSPs have become the paradigm of choice to address combinatorial problems by drawing and integrating insights from various areas, including artificial intelligence and surgical research (Rossi et al., 2006). Formally, a CSP is a tuple < X, C >, where: • X = {x1,., xn} is a finite variable.

sections.heading: 2.3 Distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problems
sections.text: When the elements of a CSP are distributed among a set of autonomous agents, we call it the Distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problem (DisCSP) (Yokoo, Durfee, Ishida, & Kuwabara, 1998; Yokoo, 2001). Formally, a DisCSP is described by a tuple < A, X, D, C, α >, where X, D, and C are the set of variables whose domains and set of constraints are defined in a CSP; A = {a1,..., am} is a finite set of autonomous agents; and α: X → A is a surjective function, from variables to agents, which assigns the control of each variable x x x x x x to an agent x. The goal of a DisCSP is to find a complete mapping that satisfies all the limitations of the problem; and α: X → A can be considered an extension of the problem groups to the problem agents, in which the individual agents assign the control of each variable x x x to the control agents, so that we each pass the control values to the other more detailed in 2006.

sections.heading: 2.4 Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems
sections.text: Similar to generalizing CSPs to COP, the Distributed Constraint Optimization Problem (DCOP) (Modi et al., 2005; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Gershman et al., 2009; Yeoh & Yokoo, 2012) turns out to be a generalization of the DisCSP model, in which constraints indicate a certain degree of preference over their violation, rather than a Boolean measure of satisfaction. DCOPs can also be seen as an extension of the COP framework to the multi-agent case, in which actors must control variables and constraints and coordinate the value allocation for the variables they control in order to optimize a global target function.

sections.heading: 4. Classical DCOP
sections.text: With regard to our classical DCOP categorization (Modi et al., 2005; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Gershman et al., 2009; Yeoh & Yokoo, 2012), the actors are fully cooperative, have deterministic behavior and total knowledge, and the environment is static and deterministic. In this section, we review the formal definitions of classical DCOPs, present some relevant solution algorithms, and provide details on selected variants of classical DCOPs of particular interest.

sections.text: A classical DCOP is described by a tuple P = < A, X, D, F, α > functions, where: • A = {a1,.., am} is a finite set of agents. • X = {x1,.., xn} is a finite set of variables, with n ≥ m. • D = {D1,.., Dn} is a finite set of agents for the variables in X, where Di is the domain of variables xi. • F = {f1,.,., fk} is a finite set of objective functions, with fi: "xj, xi, Dj, xi, R +, {}, where the WCSPs are the set of variables relevant to fi, relative to the scope of fi. Each function fi represents a factor in a global objective function.

sections.heading: 4.2 DCOP: Representation and Coordination
sections.text: Representation in DCOPs plays a fundamental role, both from the perspective of agent coordination and from an algorithmic perspective. Here, we will discuss the most dominant representations used in various DCOP algorithms. Let's start by describing some common assumptions regarding agent knowledge and coordination that apply in this document, unless otherwise stated: i. A variable and its scope are known only to the agent controlling it and its adjacent agents. ii. Each agent knows the cost value of the restrictions affecting at least one of its local variables. No other agent has knowledge of such limitations. ii. each agent knows only its own adjacent agents (and can communicate with them).

sections.heading: 4.2.2 PSEUDO-TREE
sections.text: A number of DCOP algorithms require a partial arrangement among the agents. In particular, if such an arrangement is derived from a depth-oriented search (DFS), the resulting structure is known as a (DFS) pseudo-tree. A pseudo-tree arrangement for a DCOP is a subgraph TP = < X, ET > ofGP, so that TP is a spanning tree of the GP - i.e., a connected subgraph of the GP that contains all nodes and is a rooted tree - with the following additional condition: for each x, y, X, if {x, y} xi for some fi F, then x, y appears in the same branch of the TP (i.e., x is an ancestor ancestor of the Y in TP or vice versa). Edges of the GP that lie in (or outside of) ET are referred to as tree borders (or backkedges) pseudo-variations.

sections.text: Another way to represent DCOPs is to use a factor graph (Kschischang, Frey, & Loeliger, 2001).A factor graph is a two-sided graph used to represent the factorization of a function. Specifically, the corresponding factor graph FP = < X, F, EF >, taking into account the global objective function Fg, is composed of variable nodes xi-X, factor nodes fj-F, and edge-EF, so that there is an undirected edge between factor nodes fj and variable node xi when xi-xj.factor graphs explicitly handle k-like constraints, using a method similar to that used in pseudo-trees with such constraints: You delegate control of a factor node to one of the agents that control a variable to the extent of the constraint. From an algorithmic perspective, the algorithms designed via factor constraints can deal directly with the constraints of the algorithm while docking.

sections.heading: 4.3 Algorithms
sections.text: The range of classical DCOPs is mature, and a number of different resolution algorithms have been proposed. DCOP algorithms can be classified as either complete or incomplete, based on whether they can guarantee the optimal solution, or whether they trade in optimization for shorter execution times, resulting in near-optimal solutions. They can also be characterized by their runtime characteristics (e.g., their runtime complexity and whether they are always available algorithms), their storage requirements, and their communication requirements (e.g., the number and size of messages they send, and whether they communicate via peer-to-peer channels or by transmission to all agents). Table 4 tabulates the properties of a number of important DCOP algorithms, which we will describe in more detail in Sections 4.3.4 and 4.3.5. Since all of these algorithms were originally developed on the assumption that each agent controls exactly one variable, we will also describe the properties under these assumptions in the algorithms.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 PARTIAL CENTRALIZATION
sections.text: In general, the DCOP solution process is decentralized, which results in the DCOP algorithms following the information and communication constraints described in Section 4.2. However, some algorithms examine methods for centralizing the decisions to be made by a group of agents by delegating them to one of the agents of the group. Such approaches examine the concept of partial centralization (Hirayama & Yokoo, 1997; Mailler & Lesser, 2004; Petcu, Foltings, & Mailler, 2007) and are therefore classified as partially centralized algorithms.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 SYNCHRONICITY
sections.text: Due to the way agents update their local information, the DCOP algorithms are classified as synchronous or asynchronous (Modi et al., 2005; Farinelli, Rogers, Petcu, & Jennings, 2008; Gershman et al., 2009), while synchronous algorithms restrict agents "decisions to follow a specific order typically imposed by the chosen representational structure (Mailler & Lesser, 2004; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Pearce & Tambe, 2007). Synchronous methods tend to delay the actions of some agents, ensuring that their local view of the problem is always consistent with that of the other agents (Mailler & Lesser, 2004; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Pearce & Tambe, 2007).

sections.heading: 4.3.3 EXPLORATION PROCESS
sections.text: The resolution process applied by each algorithm can be divided into three categories (Yeoh, 2010): • Search-based methods are based on the use of search techniques to explore the space of possible solutions. These methods are often derived from appropriate search techniques developed for centralized AI search problems, such as best-first search and depth-first search. • Inference-based methods are based on dynamic programming and belief propagation techniques. These methods allow agents to exploit the structure of the constraint diagram to aggregate the costs of their neighbors, effectively reducing the problem size at each step of the algorithm. • Sample-based methods are incomplete approaches that take the search space of a function (typically a probability distribution) as a product of statistical inference. Figure 5 illustrates a taxonomy of classical DCOP algorithms. In the following sections, we briefly describe some representative algorithms and incomplete classes presented above.

sections.heading: 4.3.5 INCOMPLETE ALGORITHMS
sections.text: Since some incomplete algorithms were originally developed to maximize rewards, similar to Section 4.3.5, we also describe variants of these algorithms that minimize the cost here to maintain consistency. Max-Sum (Farinelli et al., 2008) is an incomplete, synchronous, inference-based algorithm based on faith propagation, operating on factor charts by performing a process of marginalization of cost functions and optimizing the cost of each given variable, this process is accomplished by recursive propagation of messages between variable nodes and functional nodes, taking into account their impact on the marginalized cost function. Max-Sum is guaranteed to achieve an optimal solution in acyclic graphs, but convergence is not guaranteed on cyclic graphs. In the worst case, Max-Sum agents perform operations.

sections.heading: 4.4 Tradeoffs Between the Various DCOP Algorithms
sections.text: The various DCOP algorithms discussed above provide good coverage of many different characteristics that can be important in different applications. Therefore, the suitability of an algorithm for an application depends on how well the characteristics of the algorithm match the characteristics of the application. We will now discuss below some suggestions for the types of algorithms that we recommend based on the characteristics of the respective application.

sections.heading: 4.4.1 COMPLETE ALGORITHMS
sections.text: In general, we make the following recommendations if you limit yourself to complete algorithms only (e.g., if optimality is a requirement of the application): • If the agents in the application have large amounts of memory and it is faster to send a few large messages than many small messages, then DPOP is preferred to search-based algorithms (e.g. SyncBB, AFB, ADOPT, ConcFB, OptAPO). • If the agents in the application have limited amounts of memory, then you have to use the search-based algorithms (e.g. SyncBB, AFB, ADOPT, ConcFB, OptAPO), so the total runtime when using DPOP is usually smaller than when using the search algorithms. • If the agents in the application have limited amounts of memory, then you have to use the search-based algorithms (e.g. SyncBB, AFB, ADOPT, ConcFB, OptAPO) that have low memory requirements.

sections.heading: 4.4.2 INCOMPLETE ALGORITHMS
sections.text: Regarding incomplete algorithms, we make the following recommendations: • If the returned solution must have an accompanying quality guarantee, then one can choose touse Bounded Max-Sum, region-optimal algorithms, DUCT, or D-Gibbs. Bounded Max-Sum allows users to choose the error-bound as a function of the various subsets of edges that can be removed from the graph to make them acyclic. Region-optimal algorithms allow users to parameterize the error that is tied to the size of the region or the number of hops for which the solution should be optimal. Finally, DUCT and D-Gibbs allow the user to parameterize the error-bound value based on the number of sampling iterations. The error limits for these two algorithms are also probable limits (i.e. the probability that the quality of the solution lies within an error limit is a function of the number of iterations).

sections.heading: 4.5 Notable Variant: Asymmetric DCOPs
sections.text: Asymmetric DCOPs (Grinshpoun, Grubshtein, Zivan, Netzer, & Meisels, 2013) are used to model multi-agent problems where agents controlling variables within a cost function may incur different costs due to a fixed join assignment.

sections.heading: 5. Dynamic DCOPs
sections.text: Within a real MAS application, actors often operate in dynamic environments that evolve over time. Thus, for example, in a search-and-rescue scenario in the event of a disaster, new information (such as the number of victims in specific locations or priorities for the buildings to be evacuated) typically becomes available step by step. Therefore, the flow of information changes the environment over time. To meet such a requirement, researchers have introduced the dynamic DCOP model (DDCOP), where cost functions can change during the problem-solving process, agents can fail and new agents can be added to the DCOP to be solved. In terms of our categorization in the D-DCOP model described in Section 3, agents are fully cooperative and have deterministic behavior and complete knowledge. On the other hand, the environment is dynamic and deterministic.

sections.heading: 5.1 Definition
sections.text: The Dynamic DCOP Model (D-DCOP) is defined as a sequence of classical DCOPs: D1,.., DT, where each Dt = < At, Xt, Dt, Ft, αt > is a DCOP that represents the problem in time step t, for 1 ≤ t ≤ T. The goal in a D-DCOP is to optimally solve the DCOP in each time step. We assume that the agents have a complete knowledge of their current environment (i.e. the current DCOP), but they are unaware of the changes in the problem in future time steps. In a dynamic system, the agents must adapt as quickly as possible to environmental changes. Stability (Dijkstra, 1974; Verfaillie & Jussien, 2005) is a central algorithmic concept in which an algorithm attempts to convert the number of steps it takes to converge into a solution of the problem.

sections.heading: 5.2 Algorithms
sections.text: In principle, one could use classical DCOP algorithms to solve the DCOP-Dt in each time step 1 ≤ t ≤ T. Dynamic environment development, however, encourages strict requirements for algorithm design so that agents can respond automatically and efficiently to environmental changes over time. D-DCOP algorithms in particular often follow the self-stabilizing property. As in the previous sections, we categorize the algorithms either completely or incompletely, depending on their ability to determine the optimal solution in each time step.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 COMPLETE ALGORITHMS
sections.text: S-DPOP (Petcu & Folding, 2005c) is a synchronous, inference-based algorithm that extends DPOP to handle dynamic environments. It consists of three self-stabilizing phases: (1) A self-stabilizing DFS pseudo-tree generation aimed at creating and maintaining a DFS pseudo-tree structure; (2) A self-stabilizing algorithm for the UTIL propagation phase; and (3) A self-stabilizing algorithm for the OPP propagation phase. These procedures work as in DPOP and they are called whenever a change in the DCOP problem sequence is detected. Petcu and Folding (2005c) discuss two self-stabilizing ADS extensions, namely superstabilization and error containment, which can be used by the next system to provide space over an ADD.

sections.text: SBDO (Billiau, Chang, & Ghose, 2012a). Support Based Distributed Optimization (SBDO) is an asynchronous, search-based algorithm that extends the Support Based Distributed Search algorithm (Harvey, Chang, & Ghose, 2007) to the multi-agent case. It uses two types of messages that try to minimize their local costs, and communicates such decisions to their neighbors via is-good news. Each agent who receives a message decides what value to assign to its own variables.

However, many applications in the real world are characterized by environments with stochastic behavior. In other words, there are exogenous events that can affect the outcome of an agent's actions. sections.heading: 7. Quantified DCOPs
sections.text: The various extensions of the DCOP model discussed so far differ in terms of drug behavior (deterministic vs. stochastical), drug knowledge (total vs. partial), environmental behavior (deterministic vs. stochastical), and environmental development (static vs. dynamic), but in terms of drug collaboration, all models assume that the agents are fully cooperative. Recently, researchers have introduced the Quantified DCOP (QDCOP) model (Matsui, Matsuo, Silaghi, Hirayama, Yokoo, & Baba, 2010), which assumes that a subset of agents is of a contrarian nature, i.e. that the agents are partially cooperative or competitive.

sections.heading: 7.1 Definition
sections.text: The Quantified DCOP (QDCOP) model (Matsui et al., 2010) matches the Quantified Constraint Satisfaction Problem (QCSP) (Benedetti, Lallouet, & Vautard, 2008) and Quantified Distributed CSP (QDCSP) models (Baba, Iwasaki, Yokoo, Silaghi, Hirayama, & Matsui, 2010; Baba, Joe, Iwasaki, & Yokoo, 2011) to the DCOPs. In QCSPs and QDCSPs, all variables are associated with quantifiers and the constraints should be met regardless of the value of the universally quantifiable variables. Similarly, existing () and universal () quantified DCOP variables can be introduced in QDCOP to distinguish the cooperative actors from the opposite influences.

sections.heading: 7.2 Algorithms
sections.text: Therefore, classical DCOP algorithms cannot be directly applied to solve QDCOPs. Matsui et al. (2010) proposed several variants of the threshold of ADOPT to solve QDCOPs, all based on a DFS pseudo-tree order. To keep the quantifier order unchanged, the pseudo-tree can be reconfigured by applying additional thresholds for each pair of nodes if necessary. All the algorithms presented here are complete and based on the intuition that universally quantified variables can be viewed as adversally quantified virtual agents with the goal of minimizing the overall goal. Following this intuition and the pseudo-tree modifications discussed above, pseudo-treebased DCOP algorithms can be expanded to solve QDCOP.Min-ADOPT (sui et).

sections.heading: 8. DCOP Applications
sections.text: DCOP models have been introduced to cover a wide range of MAS applications thanks to their ability to capture essential and basic MAS aspects, as well as support for the development of general domain-independent algorithms, including applications in wireless sensor networks, power grids and scheduling. Here, we offer a description of some of the most compelling applications and a general overview of their corresponding DCOP models. For a comprehensive list of DCOP applications categorized by DCOP classification in Table 2, see Table 5.

sections.heading: 8.2 Radio Frequency Allocation Problems
sections.text: The performance of a wireless local network (WLAN) depends on the channel allocation between adjacent access points (APs). Adjacent transmissions that take place in APs on the same channel or adjacent channels affect network performance due to transmission interference. Typically, APs in densely populated urban areas can belong to different administrative areas, whose control is delegated to different units. Therefore, a distributed approach to channel allocation is required. Cooperative channel allocation problems. In the case of a cooperative channel allocation problem (Hollos, Karl, & Wolisz, 2004; Monteiro, Pellenz, Penna, Enembreck, Souza, & Pujolle, 2012a; Monteiro, Pujolle, Pellenz, Enembreck, & Demo Souza, 2012b), the transmission rate is determined by different signal sources.

sections.heading: 8.3 Recommendation Systems
sections.text: Recommendation systems are tools that provide the user with customized information about items that provide information tailored to the characteristics and preferences of the users. Group recommendation problems. Like individual recommendations, group recommendations must take into account the preferences of all group members and formulate a recommendation that fits the entire group. Lorenzi, dos Santos, Ferreira Jr and Bazzan (2008) proposes a DCOP-based recommendation system for groups of users. The proposed DCOP solution consists of two types of agents: user agents and recommendation agents. Each user controls a decision variable that influences the user's travel decisions, while each recommendation agent controls a decision variable that optimizes the user's preferences.

sections.heading: 8.8 Supply Chain Management Problems
sections.text: The management of large companies involves managing the flow of goods from suppliers to customers. This flow of goods is referred to as the supply chain. Supply chains must be carefully managed to ensure that a sufficient amount of raw materials is available in the factories for production and a sufficient amount of processed goods to buy consumers. In addition, goods can be purchased from different producers and sold to different consumers. A problem of the supply chain is the process of identifying the participants in a supply chain who are buying / selling the goods to. In such an environment, information, decision-making and control are inherently decentralized.

sections.heading: 8.9 Traffic Flow Control Problems
sections.text: A challenge for increasing traffic demand is to enforce traffic flow management using existing infrastructure such as traffic lights, loop detectors and cameras, and to coordinate the actions of these individual devices aimed at smoothing traffic flow at the network level. Such coordinated actions often result in coherent traffic control plans that are faster and more accurately compared to those of a human transport operator (Van Katwijk, De Schutter, & Hellendoorn, 2009). Due to the distributed nature of such devices, multi-agent solutions are particularly suitable for this type of problem. Traffic light synchronization problem. This problem is the problem of finding a synchronization scheme for traffic lights at adjacent junctions that generate green waves that travel at a certain speed and are able to cross multiple junctions without stopping at red lights.

sections.heading: 9. Analyses and Perspectives on DCOPs
sections.text: DCOPs have emerged as a popular formalism for distributed thinking and coordination in multi-agent systems. It provides an elegant modeling framework that provides flexibility in both the reasoning and coordination strategies of the actors. Its ability to support notions of preferences and constraints makes it suitable for modeling a variety of multi-agent optimization problems. Preferences are a central concept of decision-making and arise in a variety of contexts in multi-agent systems. They are fundamental for analyzing human selection behavior and allow actors to express their inclinations through specific actions and behaviors. Limitations have long been studied in centralized systems (Rossi et al., 2006) and have proven to be particularly practical and efficient for modeling and solving resource allocation and scheduling problems. They are, of course, handled within DCOPs and provide a flexible and effective means to support a variety of complex decision-making systems, such as cofining and autonomy issues.

sections.heading: 10. Conclusions
sections.text: DCOPs have become a popular formalism for distributed thinking and coordination in multi-agent systems.While the theoretical basis and algorithmic framework of DCOPs have matured significantly over the last decade, their applicability lags behind in realistic areas.This survey aims to link the theoretical framework of the DCOP and solve strategies with a range of potential applications where its applicability has or could have a significant impact. In this survey, we (1) presented an analysis of the recent progress of the AAMAS community within the DCOP framework and proposed a categorization based on the characteristics of agents, environmental characteristics and the type of teamwork used.

While there are important existing surveys for Distributed Constraint Satisfaction (Yokoo & Hirayama, 2000) and Distributed Constraint Optimization (Meisels, 2008), this survey aims to comprehensively analyze and categorize the different DCOP frameworks proposed by the MAS community.

Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs) (Golomb & Baumert, 1965; Mackworth & Freuder, 1985; Apt, 2003; Rossi et al., 2006) are decision problems that involve the assignment of values to variables, under a set of specified constraints on how variable values should be related to each other.

Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs) (Golomb & Baumert, 1965; Mackworth & Freuder, 1985; Apt, 2003; Rossi et al., 2006) are decision problems that involve the assignment of values to variables, under a set of specified constraints on how variable values should be related to each other.

Over the years, CSPs have become the paradigm of choice to address hard combinatorial problems, drawing and integrating insights from diverse domains, including Artificial Intelligence and Operations Research (Rossi et al., 2006).

When the elements of a CSP are distributed among a set of autonomous agents, we refer to it as a Distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problem (DisCSP) (Yokoo, Durfee, Ishida, & Kuwabara, 1998; Yokoo, 2001).
For a more detailed treatment of the argument we address the reader to (Rossi et al., 2006) (Chapter 20).

Similar to the generalization of CSPs to COPs, the Distributed Constraint Optimization Problem (DCOP) (Modi et al., 2005; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Gershman et al., 2009; Yeoh & Yokoo, 2012) model emerges as a generalization of the DisCSP model, where constraints specify a degree of preference over their violation, rather than a boolean satisfaction metric.

Similar to the generalization of CSPs to COPs, the Distributed Constraint Optimization Problem (DCOP) (Modi et al., 2005; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Gershman et al., 2009; Yeoh & Yokoo, 2012) model emerges as a generalization of the DisCSP model, where constraints specify a degree of preference over their violation, rather than a boolean satisfaction metric.

With respect to our categorization, in the classical DCOP model (Modi et al., 2005; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Gershman et al., 2009; Yeoh & Yokoo, 2012), the agents are completely cooperative and they have deterministic behavior and total knowledge.

Finding an optimal solution for a classical DCOP is known to be NP-hard (Modi et al., 2005).

Asynchronous algorithms allow agents to update the assignment for their variables based solely on their local view of the problem, and thus independently from the actual decisions of the other agents (Modi et al., 2005; Farinelli, Rogers, Petcu, & Jennings, 2008; Gershman et al., 2009).

Asynchronous algorithms allow agents to update the assignment for their variables based solely on their local view of the problem, and thus independently from the actual decisions of the other agents (Modi et al., 2005; Farinelli, Rogers, Petcu, & Jennings, 2008; Gershman et al., 2009).

In contrast, synchronous algorithms constrain the agents decisions to follow a particular order, typically enforced by the representation structure adopted (Mailler & Lesser, 2004; Petcu & Faltings, 2005b; Pearce & Tambe, 2007). Synchronous methods tend to delay the actions of some agents guaranteeing that their local view of the problem is always consistent with that of the other agents. In contrast, asynchronous methods tend to minimize the idle-time of the agents, which in turn can react quickly to each message being processed; however, they provide no guarantee on the consistency of the state of the local view of each agent. Such effect has been studied by Peri and Meisels (2013), concluding that inconsistent agents’ views may cause a negative impact on network load and algorithm performance, and that introducing some level of synchronization may be beneficial for some algorithms, enhancing their performance.

The algorithm extends the Iterative Constraint Generation (ICG) method (Benders, 1962; Regan & Boutilier, 2010) to the decentralized case, by decomposing the overall problem into a master problem and a subproblem that are iteratively solved until convergence.

The algorithm extends the Iterative Constraint Generation (ICG) method (Benders, 1962; Regan & Boutilier, 2010) to the decentralized case, by decomposing the overall problem into a master problem and a subproblem that are iteratively solved until convergence. At each iteration, the resolutions of these problems are attained by using Max-Sum. The master problem solves a relaxation of the minimax regret goal, where only a subset of all possible joint beliefs is considered, attempting to minimize the loss for the worst case derived from the considered joint belief. Once it generates a solution, the subproblem finds the maximally violated constraint associated to such a solution. This is referred to as the witness point, indicating that the current solution is not the best one in terms of the minimax regret. This point is added to the set of joint beliefs considered by the master problem, and the process is repeated until no new witness points can be found. The worst case runtime requirement of this algorithm is O(`|I|dl), which is dominated by the master problem, whose computation is exponential in the number of variables in the scope of the associated cost function for each belief and iteration of the algorithm. In terms of memory requirement, each ICG-Max-Sum agent needs O(|I|dl) amount of memory (dominated by the master problem again) to store all value combinations of neighboring variables for each belief. In terms of communication requirement, the number of messages sent is the same as that of Max-Sum since two parallel iterations of Max-Sum is executed in each ICG-Max-Sum iteration. However, the size of each message is O(|I|d) as it contains the aggregated cost of all the agent’s variable’s value for each belief. A variation of this algorithm that aims at minimizing the expected regret, rather than minimizing the maximum regret, was introduced by Le, Fioretto, Yeoh, Son, and Pontelli (2016).

The Quantified DCOP (QDCOP) model (Matsui et al., 2010) adapts the Quantified Constraint Satisfaction Problem (QCSP) (Benedetti, Lallouet, & Vautard, 2008) and Quantified Distributed CSP (QDCSP) (Baba, Iwasaki, Yokoo, Silaghi, Hirayama, & Matsui, 2010; Baba, Joe, Iwasaki, & Yokoo, 2011) models to DCOPs.
While finding an optimal solution for a DCOP is NP-hard, solving a QDCOP is, in general, P-SPACE-hard (Benedetti et al., 2008; Lallouet, Lee, Mak, & Yip, 2015).
Matsui et al. (2010) proposed several variations of ADOPT to solve QDCOPs, which are all based on a DFS pseudo-tree ordering.

In a Coalition Formation with Spatial and Temporal Constraints (CFST) problem (Ramchurn et al., 2010; PujolGonzalez, Cerquides, Farinelli, Meseguer, & Rodriguez-Aguilar, 2015; Steinbauer & Kleiner, 2012), ambulance and fire brigade agents cooperate in order to react efficiently to an emergency scenario so as to rescue victims and extinguish fires located in different parts of a city.

In a Coalition Formation with Spatial and Temporal Constraints (CFST) problem (Ramchurn et al., 2010; PujolGonzalez, Cerquides, Farinelli, Meseguer, & Rodriguez-Aguilar, 2015; Steinbauer & Kleiner, 2012), ambulance and fire brigade agents cooperate in order to react efficiently to an emergency scenario so as to rescue victims and extinguish fires located in different parts of a city. Agents can travel from one location to another in a given time. Each task (i.e., rescuing a victim, extinguishing a fire) has a deadline, representing the time until which the victim will survive, and a workload, denoting the amount of time necessary to rescue the victim or put out the fire. The locations of the victims and the fires may be unknown to the agents, and need to be discovered at runtime, which requires agents to dynamically update the sequence of the tasks they will attempt, taking account of two main constraints: (1) Spatial constraints, which model where an agent can travel and at what time; and (2) Temporal constraints, which model task deadlines and completion times. Agents may also form coalitions to execute a given task faster or if the requirements of a given task cannot be met by a single agent. Hence, the agents’ arrival times at each task need to be coordinated in order to form the desired coalition. The objective is to maximize the number of tasks to be completed. A DCOP formalization for the CFST is described by Ramchurn et al. (2010), where ambulances and fire brigades are modeled as DCOP agents.

In a Coalition Formation with Spatial and Temporal Constraints (CFST) problem (Ramchurn et al., 2010; PujolGonzalez, Cerquides, Farinelli, Meseguer, & Rodriguez-Aguilar, 2015; Steinbauer & Kleiner, 2012), ambulance and fire brigade agents cooperate in order to react efficiently to an emergency scenario so as to rescue victims and extinguish fires located in different parts of a city. Agents can travel from one location to another in a given time. Each task (i.e., rescuing a victim, extinguishing a fire) has a deadline, representing the time until which the victim will survive, and a workload, denoting the amount of time necessary to rescue the victim or put out the fire. The locations of the victims and the fires may be unknown to the agents, and need to be discovered at runtime, which requires agents to dynamically update the sequence of the tasks they will attempt, taking account of two main constraints: (1) Spatial constraints, which model where an agent can travel and at what time; and (2) Temporal constraints, which model task deadlines and completion times. Agents may also form coalitions to execute a given task faster or if the requirements of a given task cannot be met by a single agent. Hence, the agents’ arrival times at each task need to be coordinated in order to form the desired coalition. The objective is to maximize the number of tasks to be completed. A DCOP formalization for the CFST is described by Ramchurn et al. (2010), where ambulances and fire brigades are modeled as DCOP agents. Each agent controls a variable that encodes the current task that the agent will attempt, and whose domain represents task locations. Unary constraints restrict the set of reachable locations, according to distance from a destination and the victim’s deadline. Agents’ coalitions are defined as groups of agents traveling to the same location. Each task is associated to a utility, which encodes the success for a coalition to complete such task. The goal is to find an assignment of agents to tasks that maximizes the overall utility. A variant of the CFST problem, called the Law Enforcement Problem (LEP), was introduced by Amador, Okamoto, and Zivan (2014). Similar to the CFST problem, in a LEP, police officers need to execute a number of tasks, and may form coalitions to improve their response quality.

Monteiro et al. (2012a, 2012b) proposed a DCOP-based approach for cooperative channel assignment in WLANs where APs may belong to different administration entities. In the proposed model, each AP is represented by a DCOP agent, which controls a decision variable modeling a choice for the AP’s channels. The signal-to-interference-and-noise ratio perceived by an AP or a client is modeled as a cost function, as the overall concurrent transmissions occurring in the same channel and in partially overlapped adjacent channels. The goal is to find an assignment of channels to APs that minimizes the total interference experienced in the WLAN. Xie, Howitt, and Raja (2007) and Mir, Merghem-Boulahia, and Gaı̈ti (2010) study dynamic solutions to the problem of allocating and utilizing the wireless network’s available spectrum.

Scheduling problems are an important class of problems, and they have been long studied in the area of Constraint Programming and Operations Research (Giffler & Thompson, 1960; Solomon, 1987; Minton, Johnston, Philips, & Laird, 1992; Hentenryck & Michel, 2009).

The distributed meeting scheduling problem captures generic scheduling problems where one wishes to schedule a set of events within a time range (Jennings & Jackson, 1995; Garrido & Sycara, 1996). Each event is defined by: (i) the resources required for it to be completed, (ii) the time required for it to be completed, within which it holds the required resources, and (iii) the cost of using such resources at a given time. A scheduling conflict occurs if two events with at least one common resource are scheduled in overlapping time slots. The goal is to maximize the utilities over all the resources, defined as the net gain between the opportunity benefit and opportunity cost of scheduling various events. Maheswaran, Tambe, Bowring, Pearce, and Varakantham (2004b) discuss three possible DCOP formulations for this problem: Time slots as variables (TSAV), events as variables (EAV), and private events as variables (PEAV).
Giuliani et al. (2014) formalize a regulatory mechanism in water management as a DCOP.
Li et al. (2016) proposed a DCOP model for the VRPP, where vessels and terminals are modeled as DCOP agents.

Hannebauer and Müller (2001) formulate the problem of scheduling patients to diagnostic units in an hospital as a DCOP, where appointments are modeled as variables, whose domains describe times, durations, and locations.

In a typical target tracking application (Zhang et al., 2005; Matsui & Matsuo, 2008; Jain, Taylor, Tambe, & Yokoo, 2009; Ota, Matsui, & Matsuo, 2009; Stranders, Farinelli, Rogers, & Jennings, 2009; Semnani & Basir, 2013), a collection of small Doppler sensors are scattered in an area to detect possible moving targets in the region.

Each sensor is batterypowered, can communicate with one another through radio communication, and can scan and detect an object within a fixed range. Communication incurs an energy cost. Thus, to save energy, a sensor may turn itself off. Multiple sensors may be necessary to detect a single target with high accuracy. The overall objective is to maximize the number of targets detected, as quickly as possible and, at the same time, preserve energy so as to prolong the system’s lifetime Zhang et al. (2005) moldes a simplified version of the above problem as a weighted graph coloring problem, where the total weight of violated constraints needs to be minimized.

A node corresponds to a sensor, an edge between two nodes represents the constraint of a shared region between agents, and the weight captures the importance of the common region. The size of the common region reflects the amount of energy loss when two sensors scan the shared region at the same time. Each color corresponds to a time slot in which a sector is scanned. A node must have at least one color so that the corresponding sector is scanned at least once. This graph coloring problem is mapped to a DCOP, where agents represent nodes, agent’s variables represent the agents decision on their color, and cost functions represent the graph edges. Semnani and Basir (2013) use a hierarchical DCOP approach to scale to larger problems.

de Oliveira, Bazzan, and Lesser (2005) and Junges and Bazzan (2008) model this problem as a DCOP, where agents represent traffic lights, each controlling one variable that models the coordination direction for the associated traffic signal.

de Oliveira, Bazzan, and Lesser (2005) and Junges and Bazzan (2008) model this problem as a DCOP, where agents represent traffic lights, each controlling one variable that models the coordination direction for the associated traffic signal. Thus, the domain of the variables is given by two possible directions of coordination (north-south/south-north, east-west/west-east). Conflicts that arise when two neighboring traffic signals choose different directions are modeled as constraints. Cost functions are defined to model the number of incoming vehicles in a junction, and the costs are influenced by whether two adjacent agents agree on a direction of coordination or not. The goal is to minimize the global cost. Due to the dynamic nature of the problem, the proposed algorithms fall under the umbrella of Dynamic DCOP algorithms. Constraints have been long studied in centralized systems (Rossi et al., 2006) and have been proved especially practical and efficient for modeling and solving resource allocation and scheduling problems.

For instance, as outlined by Kumar and Zilberstein (2011) and Ghosh, Kumar, and Varakantham (2015), one can use inference-based algorithms, such as expectation-maximization, and convex optimization machinery to develop efficient message-passing algorithm for solving large DCOPs.

For instance, as outlined by Kumar and Zilberstein (2011) and Ghosh, Kumar, and Varakantham (2015), one can use inference-based algorithms, such as expectation-maximization, and convex optimization machinery to develop efficient message-passing algorithm for solving large DCOPs.
Within the current incomplete methods proposed, a considerable effort has been employed in developing anytime algorithms (Zilberstein, 1996).

In addition to the anytime mechanism, which constrains the problem resolution within a particular time requirement, any-space algorithms have been proposed to limit the amount of space needed to an agent during problem resolution (Petcu & Faltings, 2007a; Yeoh et al., 2009b, 2011; Gutierrez et al., 2011).
For example, Zhang and Lesser (2013) study agent learning, where coordination is driven by a dynamic decomposition of a DCOP, each solving smaller independent subproblems.

There are two commonly used reformulation techniques (Burke & Brown, 2006; Yokoo, 2001): (i) Compilation (or complex variables) where each agent creates a new pseudo-variable whose domain is the Cartesian product of the domains of all variables of the agent; and (ii) Decomposition (or virtual agents) where each agent creates a pseudo-agent for each of its variables.

One can even exploit novel hardware platforms, such as graphical processing units (GPUs) to parallelize such solvers (Fioretto et al., 2016a; Fioretto, Le, Yeoh, Pontelli, & Son, 2015; Bistaffa, Farinelli, & Bombieri, 2014). Researchers have proposed re-designed versions of existing algorithms to be able to handle multi-variables agents problems (Davin & Modi, 2006; Khanna, Sattar, Hansen, & Stantic, 2009; Portway & Durfee, 2010). Additionally, recently, Grinshpoun (2015) and Fioretto, Yeoh, and Pontelli (2016b) have proposed general DCOP problem decompositions which are able to solve problems where agents control multiple variables.

One can even exploit novel hardware platforms, such as graphical processing units (GPUs) to parallelize such solvers (Fioretto et al., 2016a; Fioretto, Le, Yeoh, Pontelli, & Son, 2015; Bistaffa, Farinelli, & Bombieri, 2014). Researchers have proposed re-designed versions of existing algorithms to be able to handle multi-variables agents problems (Davin & Modi, 2006; Khanna, Sattar, Hansen, & Stantic, 2009; Portway & Durfee, 2010). Additionally, recently, Grinshpoun (2015) and Fioretto, Yeoh, and Pontelli (2016b) have proposed general DCOP problem decompositions which are able to solve problems where agents control multiple variables.

There are currently several MAS simulators which have been adopted by researchers to develop and compare DCOP algorithms: • DisChoco (Wahbi et al., 2011) is a Java open-source framework for simulating DCOP algorithms where agents are executed asynchronously (each in a separate execution thread) and communication is implemented via messages passing.

• Frodo (Léauté et al., 2009) is a Java open-source framework for DCOP which implements several complete and incomplete classic DCOP algorithms, including DPOP and some of it variants, Max-Sum, MGM, and DSA.

For a comprehensive review of multi-agent platforms, we refer the interested reader to the survey by Kravari and Bassiliades (2015). The development of DCOP simulators have provided researchers with useful tools to develop new DCOP algorithms and to facilitate comparison of existing DCOP algorithms.

There are multiple metrics that can be used to measure the runtime of an algorithm, such as the number of non-concurrent constraint checks (NCCCs) (Meisels, Kaplansky, Razgon, & Zivan, 2002), the simulated runtime (Sultanik, Lass, & Regli, 2008), and the number of cycles (Lynch, 1996).

metadata.abstractText: The field of Multi-Agent System (MAS) is an active area of research within Artificial Intelligence, with an increasingly important impact in industrial and other real-world applications. In a MAS, autonomous agents interact to pursue personal interests and/or to achieve common objectives. Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs) have emerged as a prominent agent model to govern the agents’ autonomous behavior, where both algorithms and communication models are driven by the structure of the specific problem. During the last decade, several extensions to the DCOP model have been proposed to enable support of MAS in complex, realtime, and uncertain environments. This survey provides an overview of the DCOP model, offering a classification of its multiple extensions and addressing both resolution methods and applications that find a natural mapping within each class of DCOPs. The proposed classification suggests several future perspectives for DCOP extensions, and identifies challenges in the design of efficient resolution algorithms, possibly through the adaptation of strategies from different areas.
